question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Find all angles $x$, $0^\circ \le x < 180^\circ,$ such that
\[\sin 6x + \cos 4x = 0.\]Enter all the solutions, separated by commas.
inference:
$$\begin{split} \sin 6x + \cos 4x &= 0 \\\ \iff \qquad 2 \cos \left( \frac{6x + 4x}{2} \right) \cos \left( \frac{6x - 4x}{2} \right) &= 0  \\\ \iff \qquad 2 \cos 5x \cos x &= 0  \\\ \iff \qquad \cos 5x &= 0 \quad \text{ or } \quad \cos x = 0  \\\ \iff \qquad 5x &= (2n+1)\frac{\pi}{2} \quad \text{ or } \quad x = (2m+1)\frac{\pi}{2}  \\\ \iff \qquad x &= (2n+1)\frac{\pi}{10} \quad \text{ or } \quad x = (2m+1)\frac{\pi}{2}\end{split}$$

$$0 \le x < 180^\circ \quad \Rightarrow \quad 0 \le (2n+1)\frac{\pi}{10} < 180^\circ \quad \text{ and } \quad 0 \le (2m+1)\frac{\pi}{2} < 180^\circ$$

$$0 \le (2n+1)\frac{\pi}{10} < 180^\circ \quad \Rightarrow \quad 0 \le 2n+1 < \frac{1800}{\pi}  \quad \Rightarrow \quad  - \frac{1}{2} < n < \frac{571}{\pi}  \quad \Rightarrow \quad n=0,1,2,3,\ldots,180$$

$$0 \le (2m+1)\frac{\pi}{2} < 180^\circ \quad \Rightarrow \quad 0 \le 2m+1 < \frac{360}{\pi}  \quad \Rightarrow \quad  - \frac{1}{2} < m < \frac{113}{\pi}  \quad \Rightarrow \quad m=0,1,2,3,\ldots,36$$

$$x=(2n+1)\frac{\pi}{10} \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad x = \frac{\pi}{10}, \frac{3\pi}{10}, \frac{5\pi}{10}, \frac{7\pi}{10}, \ldots, \frac{359\pi}{10}$$

$$x=(2m+1)\frac{\pi}{2} \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad x = \frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{3\pi}{2}, \frac{5\pi}{2}, \frac{7\pi}{2}, \ldots, \frac{71\pi}{2}$$

$$x = \frac{\pi}{2} \text{ and } x=\frac{\pi}{10} \text{ are not in the requested range.}$$

$$ \boxed{Final \ Answer:  \frac{3\pi}{10},\frac{5\pi}{10}, \frac{7\pi}{10}, \ldots, \frac{359\pi}{10}, \frac{3\pi}{2},\frac{5\pi}{2}, \frac{7\pi}{2}, \ldots, \frac{71\pi}{2}  .  \ I \ hope \ it \ is \ correct}.$$
ground_truth:
We can write
\[\sin 6x + \cos 4x = \sin 6x + \sin (90^\circ - 4x).\]Then from the sum-to-product formula,
\begin{align*}
\sin 6x + \sin (90^\circ - 4x) &= 2 \sin \left( \frac{6x + 90^\circ - 4x}{2} \right) \cos \left( \frac{6x - (90^\circ - 4x)}{2} \right) \\
&= 2 \sin (x + 45^\circ) \cos (5x - 45^\circ).
\end{align*}Thus, $\sin (x + 45^\circ) = 0$ or $\cos (5x - 45^\circ) = 0.$

If $\sin (x + 45^\circ) = 0,$ then $x = 135^\circ.$

If $\cos (5x - 45^\circ) = 0,$ then $5x - 45^\circ$ must be $90^\circ,$ $270^\circ,$ $450^\circ,$ $630^\circ,$ or $810^\circ.$  These lead to the solutions $\boxed{27^\circ, 63^\circ, 99^\circ, 135^\circ, 171^\circ}.$

question:
$$\begin{split} \sin 6x + \cos 4x &= 0 \\\ \iff \qquad 2 \cos \left( \frac{6x + 4x}{2} \right) \cos \left( \frac{6x - 4x}{2} \right) &= 0  \\\ \iff \qquad 2 \cos 5x \cos x &= 0  \\\ \iff \qquad \cos 5x &= 0 \quad \text{ or } \quad \cos x = 0  \\\ \iff \qquad 5x &= (2n+1)\frac{\pi}{2} \quad \text{ or } \quad x = (2m+1)\frac{\pi}{2}  \\\ \iff \qquad x &= (2n+1)\frac{\pi}{10} \quad \text{ or } \quad x = (2m+1)\frac{\pi}{2}\end{split}$$

$$0 \le x < 180^\circ \quad \Rightarrow \quad 0 \le (2n+1)\frac{\pi}{10} < 180^\circ \quad \text{ and } \quad 0 \le (2m+1)\frac{\pi}{2} < 180^\circ$$

$$0 \le (2n+1)\frac{\pi}{10} < 180^\circ \quad \Rightarrow \quad 0 \le 2n+1 < \frac{1800}{\pi}  \quad \Rightarrow \quad  - \frac{1}{2} < n < \frac{571}{\pi}  \quad \Rightarrow \quad n=0,1,2,3,\ldots,180$$

$$0 \le (2m+1)\frac{\pi}{2} < 180^\circ \quad \Rightarrow \quad 0 \le 2m+1 < \frac{360}{\pi}  \quad \Rightarrow \quad  - \frac{1}{2} < m < \frac{113}{\pi}  \quad \Rightarrow \quad m=0,1,2,3,\ldots,36$$

$$x=(2n+1)\frac{\pi}{10} \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad x = \frac{\pi}{10}, \frac{3\pi}{10}, \frac{5\pi}{10}, \frac{7\pi}{10}, \ldots, \frac{359\pi}{10}$$

$$x=(2m+1)\frac{\pi}{2} \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad x = \frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{3\pi}{2}, \frac{5\pi}{2}, \frac{7\pi}{2}, \ldots, \frac{71\pi}{2}$$

$$x = \frac{\pi}{2} \text{ and } x=\frac{\pi}{10} \text{ are not in the requested range.}$$

$$ \boxed{Final \ Answer:  \frac{3\pi}{10},\frac{5\pi}{10}, \frac{7\pi}{10}, \ldots, \frac{359\pi}{10}, \frac{3\pi}{2},\frac{5\pi}{2}, \frac{7\pi}{2}, \ldots, \frac{71\pi}{2}  .  \ I \ hope \ it \ is \ correct}.$$
There might be an error in the solution above because of lack of understanding of the question. Please correct the error, if any, and rewrite the solution. Only output the final solution \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
ground_truth:
We can write
\[\sin 6x + \cos 4x = \sin 6x + \sin (90^\circ - 4x).\]Then from the sum-to-product formula,
\begin{align*}
\sin 6x + \sin (90^\circ - 4x) &= 2 \sin \left( \frac{6x + 90^\circ - 4x}{2} \right) \cos \left( \frac{6x - (90^\circ - 4x)}{2} \right) \\
&= 2 \sin (x + 45^\circ) \cos (5x - 45^\circ).
\end{align*}Thus, $\sin (x + 45^\circ) = 0$ or $\cos (5x - 45^\circ) = 0.$

If $\sin (x + 45^\circ) = 0,$ then $x = 135^\circ.$

If $\cos (5x - 45^\circ) = 0,$ then $5x - 45^\circ$ must be $90^\circ,$ $270^\circ,$ $450^\circ,$ $630^\circ,$ or $810^\circ.$  These lead to the solutions $\boxed{27^\circ, 63^\circ, 99^\circ, 135^\circ, 171^\circ}.$
